name: Multigrain Dosa
instructions: Add Bajra, Jowar, Chana Dal, Urad Dal, Moong Dal, Fenugreek Seeds, and Rice into a bowl.
Add water and scrub the grains well for 1-2 minutes to remove muddy water. Rinse and add fresh water.
Soak the mixture overnight or for at least 2 hours if in a hurry, to make the grains soft.
After soaking, check the grains to ensure they are soft.
Grind the soaked mixture with a little water. Start with less water and add more gradually to make a smooth batter.
Ensure the batter is thick but has a pouring consistency, meaning it should fall from the ladle but remain thick.
If time permits, allow the batter to ferment by covering it with a lid and leaving it in the kitchen (not in the fridge) for 12 hours. Fermented batter is healthier.
If needed instantly, the batter can be used directly without fermentation.
Before cooking, add Salt, Turmeric (optional), and Powdered Sugar (optional for a nice brown colour). Mix well.
Heat the Tawa properly. Add water to create steam and clean the Tawa.
Pour a ladle of batter in the centre of the Tawa and spread it confidently with a light hand.
Increase the flame and cook the Dosa properly.
Add Melted Ghee (or Oil) on the Dosa for taste.
Once cooked, fold the Dosa and serve hot.

name: Dal Chutney (South Indian Style)
instructions: Heat a pan and add some Oil.
Add Asafoetida and Raw Toor Dal (without soaking) to the pan.
Roast the Toor Dal on medium flame for 3-4 minutes until it becomes crispy.
Add Coriander, Cumin, Garlic, and Sambar Onion (or regular Onion) to the pan.
Roast for 3-4 minutes.
Add Kashmiri Red Chilli and Curry Leaves, and roast for another 3-4 minutes. Turn off the gas.
Let the mixture cool slightly before grinding.
While grinding, add Tamarind (without seeds) and a little water as required to make a thick Chutney.
Once ground, the Chutney is ready. It is a Dal Chutney without Coconut, South Indian Style.
For extra flavour, prepare a Tadka by heating a little Oil and adding Mustard Seeds.
When the Mustard Seeds pop, add Urad Dal and Curry Leaves to the Tadka.
Pour the Tadka directly over the Chutney and mix well.
Serve the Chutney fresh. It can be stored in the fridge for up to 2 days but not longer because it contains raw water.
